title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" and it enhances program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Act authorizes enhanced oversight periods and enrollment moratoria when the Secretary determines a significant risk of fraudulent activity among providers or suppliers. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers or suppliers under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI based on data analysis or claims submissions, to address fraudulent activity. The Secretary can impose requirements on providers or suppliers under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations. The Secretary may require States to implement provisions for enhanced oversight, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations under title XIX and XXI. The Secretary may require a State to implement provisions for enhanced oversight, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations under title XIX and XXI. Actions and determinations made under this subsection are not subject to judicial review. Screening procedures for providers and suppliers will be established by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish screening procedures for providers and suppliers, including licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, background checks, and site visits. The Secretary will establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers and suppliers, including background checks, site visits, and heightened disclosure of affiliations, lasting 30 to 365 days. The Secretary will establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers and suppliers, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and enhanced claims review for a period of 30 to 365 days, with the possibility of extension if deemed necessary. The Secretary may extend oversight period for programs under titles XVIII, XIX, and XXI beyond 365 days if necessary. Enhanced oversight for claims of DME suppliers in identified categories or areas under title XVIII due to significant risk of fraudulent activity. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment from suppliers in identified categories or areas under title XVIII due to significant risk of fraudulent activity. Periodic review of physician authorizations will be conducted for oversight purposes. The Secretary establishes a program for periodic review of physician authorizations to address excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services. Physicians or professionals receive a quarterly list for oversight. The Secretary implements a program for monitoring excessive prescribing or authorization of items or services by physicians or healthcare professionals. They receive quarterly lists of claims based on their prescriptions or authorizations, and must validate the legitimacy of identified claims within a 90-day period. The Secretary enforces a program to monitor excessive prescribing by physicians or healthcare professionals. They must validate identified claims within 90 days, or subsequent claims will be denied. Additionally, a moratorium on enrolling providers and suppliers is in place. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrolling providers and suppliers in certain cases of ongoing fraud within specific healthcare programs under title XVIII, XIX, or XXI. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrolling providers and suppliers in specific healthcare programs if ongoing fraud is detected. This moratorium must not impact individuals' access to care. States can conduct provider screening and oversight activities beyond federal requirements. The Secretary will establish procedures to determine the legitimacy of new providers and suppliers during a probationary period. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrolling providers and suppliers in healthcare programs if fraud is detected. States can conduct additional provider screening and oversight activities. A probationary period will be established to determine the legitimacy of new providers and suppliers. During XVIII, XIX, or XXI, a probationary period with heightened review (up to 1 year) will be implemented by the Secretary to validate provider operations and physician prescriptions for items and services. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate after a review. This action is subject to the provisions of section 1128. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation with notice, subject to section 1128 provisions. Failure to cooperate in prescription validation may result in a civil monetary penalty up to $10,000. The Secretary may impose a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000 on providers or suppliers who fail to cooperate in prescription validation. Sections 1816(c)(2) and 1842(c)(2) of the Act are amended regarding prompt pay provisions. The Secretary can impose a penalty on providers or suppliers for non-cooperation in prescription validation. Amendments are made to prompt pay provisions in sections 1816(c)(2) and 1842(c)(2) of the Act. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act regarding claims of providers or suppliers in cases of suspicious or potentially fraudulent claim submissions. Amendments to the Social Security Act include provisions for enforcing moratoriums on certain entities and ensuring state enforcement of regulations. Amendments to the Social Security Act include provisions for state enforcement of determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. The Social Security Act amendments require states to enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers. States must carry out activities as required by the Secretary for program integrity in State child health plans. State child health plans must include procedures to enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers, as well as carry out activities required by the Secretary for program integrity. The amendments made by the State child health plans must include procedures to enforce determinations regarding fraudulent activity by providers or suppliers and carry out activities required by the Secretary for program integrity. The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of section 1128G apply to enrollments and renewals of providers of services and suppliers under Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services consults with the Inspector General to identify providers, suppliers, or services at risk of fraudulent activity under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services consults with the Inspector General to identify providers, suppliers, or services at risk of fraudulent activity under Medicare, Medicaid, or the State children's health insurance program. Additional funding may be appropriated for this purpose. Additional funding is authorized to be appropriated for carrying out the amendments made by this section. The effective date for the amendments is upon the enactment of the Act, with expedited implementation for approved providers and suppliers. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. Regulations for implementation will be finalized within 6 months of the enactment date. Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment, which will be final immediately on an interim basis. The Secretary will allow for public comments on the interim regulation and may make changes after the comment period.
